Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Atlas of Lie Groups and Representations: Computational Aspects
Award.AbstractNarration:
The primary goal of The Atlas of Lie Groups and Representations project is to solve a fundamental problem in representation theory of Lie groups: the classification of the irreducible unitary representations of real reductive Lie groups. The contributors are taking a computational approach to the problem. They have developed the mathematical theory required to reduce the problem to a finite computation. This required rethinking representation theory from the ground up from this new point of view. The key tool is a modified notion of invariant Hermitian form, called the c-Hermitian form, which has critical uniqueness properties lacking in the usual Hermitian form. This allows the formulation of an algorithm to compute the sign of c-Hermitian and Hermitian forms, in terms of a new family of Kazhdan-Lusztig-Vogan polynomials.

Symmetry plays a fundamental role in mathematics and the sciences. In the late 19th century Sophus Lie showed that the symmetry of a system can be captured in an abstract mathematical object; these are now known as Lie (pronounced Lee) groups. The ways in which a particular symmetry (i.e. Lie) group can manifest itself are known as unitary representations. The main goal of the Atlas of Lie Groups and Representations is to understand all such representations. This has applications to physics, as well as many areas of mathematics, including number theory and geometry. The approach is computational. Both the mathematical and computational challenges are great, and the project brings together mathematicians and computer scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lie groups are fascinating, complicated mathematical objects characterized by algebraic and geometric structures which are compatible with each other. They consist of continuous families of symmetries. For example, the Lie group O(2) is made up of the symmetries of the circle: rotations by arbitrary angles, and reflections about any line passing through the center of the circle will take the circle to itself. This family (rotations and reflections together) is an example of a one-dimensional Lie group. There are Lie groups of every size and dimension. For example, the Lie group E8 has dimension 248. As families of symmetries, Lie groups appear naturally when studying any number of phenomena, in all areas of mathematics, in physics (in particular quantum mechanics and particle physics), as well as in chemistry.

 

One way to study and try to understand Lie groups is by looking at their “representations”; i.e., how they act on other spaces. For example, the group O(2) “acts” on the plane (a two-dimensional space) by moving points through rotations and reflections, but also, in a similar way, it acts on larger spaces. Especially interesting are representations that are length-preserving, the unitary representations. While classical results provide a list of all representations of a given Lie group, determining which of these are unitary is in general a fascinating and difficult (still open) problem. The present project is part of a large collaborative effort, the Atlas of Lie Groups project, with the goal to solve this problem.

 

At the heart of the project is the Atlas software: a computer program that performs a number of calculations involving Lie groups. The motivating goal for the software has been accomplished (largely, but not completely, as part of earlier grant activities by the team): given a representation of a Lie group (of size restricted by the software capabilities, but including all forms of, for example, E8), the software determines whether it is unitary or not, and provides much additional and very useful supporting information. In addition to being able to determine unitarity, the software has many other related capabilities, and we are continuously adding more functionalities related to answering questions about the structure and representation theory of Lie groups. The software is becoming a valuable tool for researchers and students in any mathematical field or science with applications to Lie groups. It can be used for discovering a wealth of information not easily accessible through books or papers, for hypothesis testing, for exploration to motivate new research questions, and as a tool for instruction. The software is freely available for downloading, and has already been used to support a number of published and unpublished research projects.

 

The main focus during the grant period has been on making the software more accessible to the mathematical and scientific community. For this purpose, we have created an “Atlas Documentation Site” which contains instructions on how to download and install the software, a library of functions with explanations, a tutorial for how to use the software, instructional videos, and a forum site for comments and questions. In addition, we have organized a two week (international) workshop to introduce the software to interested researchers and students, including a number of lectures, interactive sessions, and personalized instruction for individual projects and questions, upon request by the participants. The outcomes of this project also include a number of additions and improvements of the Atlas software such as new functions, testing and debugging, and improved efficiency. Finally, we have prepared several manuscripts on the mathematics behind the project, with examples, designed for inclusion in a monograph on the project. This book is in preparation; it is intended as a reference, as well as an instructional tool for students and researchers in mathematics.
